ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learnt to evaluate different things in life, especially with regards to medicine. It also made me more able to appreciate the lives and work of doctors. I learnt more about different authors as well.

I learned about everything: medicine, humanity, science, literature, history. This class is a deep exploration into our human nature from many perspectives, all centered around medicine. You will learn how to find your humanity in any profession, from one in medicine to one in history or literature.

I learned about uncertainty in medicine, the difficulties of the doctor-patient relationship, the responsibilities of the patient, the dueling nature of Platonism and Aristotelianism, and the importance of considering the full humanity of every individual in the healthcare system, from the patient to the physician.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I absolutely love this class. I love that I get to explore Yale's different facilities and museum and get access to books, manuscripts and other materials from different collections. I also enjoy the seminar where I can learn and expand on other's views and opinions. The books and readings were also very interesting and eye-opening.

Take this class! In Yale's long roster of professors and list of courses, this class is the HIDDEN GEM. Dr. Morrison fosters a phenomenal class atmosphere of open discussions on compelling topics that relate to so many parts of our daily lives and professions, in and outside of medicine. I cannot recommend this course enough!

Strengths: The course explored many different aspects of medicine and how they have been explored through literature. Additionally, the class was bolstered by many eye-opening class trips and guest speakers. Weaknesses: At times, the Professor's personal interests clouded the course's original intent. Some of the lectures felt loosely connected to Medicine.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. It is absolutely one of the most amazing courses you can take because it is so interesting. I absolutely love this class. I love that I get to explore Yale's different facilities and museum and get access to books, manuscripts and other materials from different collections. I also enjoy the seminar where I can learn and expand on other's views and opinions. The books and readings were also very interesting and eye-opening.

Absolutely! You are missing out if you don't take this class. It is one of the best courses in all of Yale. The class is particularly relevant in today's world because it ties in our sense of humanity into our professions. The readings and course discussions serve as a blueprint and guide for students on how to hold onto their sense of humanity as they enter into their future professions. This course will enrich with you with new perspectives. The list of readings are truly phenomenal as well -- clearly hand-picked with great thought and care for the course.
Yes, this class offers something for everyone!

narratives.question_text: The Canvas course site allowed me to identify and access required course materials easily.
How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?

extras.title: HUMS S225 01 - Medicine and the Humanities
